supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate for defensive operations, improving significantly from British 8th Army logistics. Primary supply line from Tripoli (British-controlled). Force L transitioned from austere Chad march conditions to British Army supply standards during Q2 1943.

tactical_doctrine.role: Mobile desert column operating on British 8th Army's left (inland) flank. Screening force to prevent German flanking maneuvers through southern mountain passes. Specialized in desert warfare, long-range patrol, and holding dispersed defensive positions.
special_capabilities: Desert navigation and survival (veteran Chad-to-Tripoli march experience)
Multi-national integration (Free French, British equipment, Greek squadron)
Camel Corps long-range reconnaissance unique in Allied forces
Rapid motorized deployment across difficult terrain
Defensive warfare in mountainous desert terrain (Ksar Rhilane expertise)
tactical_innovations: Combined use of modern armored cars and traditional camel scouts for reconnaissance
Dispersed defensive positions using terrain (wadis, mountain passes) to multiply force effectiveness
Integration of British armor and artillery support with French colonial infantry tactics
known_issues: Heterogeneous equipment (French, British, captured Italian) creates maintenance challenges
Limited heavy armor compared to regular divisions
Dependence on British logistics for modern weapons and ammunition
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Force L represents the pinnacle of Free French desert adaptation. Veterans of the epic Chad-to-Tripoli march (1,553 miles), they mastered water discipline, vehicle recovery in sand, and navigation by stars. The Camel Corps (méharistes) provided unmatched desert reconnaissance capability. British re-supply in Tripoli modernized equipment while preserving desert expertise.

scenario_suitability: Ksar Rhilane (10 March 1943) - Force L vs 90. leichte Division reconnaissance
Tunisia Campaign mountain pass defense scenarios
Multi-national combined arms scenarios (French, British, Greek cooperation)
special_rules: Desert Veterans: +1 to morale in desert terrain

Dispersed Defense Expertise: +1 to defense in mountainous/broken terrain
British Equipment Familiarization: May use British supply and support without penalty
Epic March Veterans: Immune to harsh desert environment penalties (represent conditioning from Chad march)
historical_engagements: Ksar Rhilane (10 March 1943) - defeated German 90. leichte Division reconnaissance force
Mareth Line operations (March 1943) - held left flank

discovered_units.combat_evidence: Greek Sacred Squadron participated in Force L operations at Ksar Rhilane (10 March 1943) and subsequent Mareth Line/Tunisia Campaign battles. Operated as reconnaissance and raiding force attached to Leclerc's command. Documented in multiple sources as integral part of Force L during Tunisia fighting (March-May 1943).
